STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 6, 2022
Jennifer Vasilovski
Family and Community Services-Macomb
Suite 110
42140 Van Dyke Ave
Sterling Heights, MI 48314
RE: License #: CB500316267
Family and Community Services-Macomb
Suite 110
42140 Van Dyke Ave
Sterling Heights, MI 48314
Dear Ms. Vasilovski:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on May 5, 2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations
please indicate why the prior CAP was unsuccessful and what changed will
be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12326 Borrowed home
(2)The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d), (g) of this rule annually for the
duration of the child’s placement.
Three of three borrowed beds did not meet this requirement.
(d) Three annual or renewal evaluation reports were not endorsed by the agency.
(g) An annually updated foster parent/agency agreement was not in one file.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as is
indicated, based on the information received, but not later than
7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
One of three special evaluations did not meet this requirement. The agency became
aware of a possible rule violation on 3/25/21. However, (a) DCWL did not receive
notification within five days and (b) a special evaluation was not initiated within
seven days. A special evaluation was not initiated until 4/14/21.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following: (c) Provide a copy of
the report to any social services worker that has children placed
in the home.
One of three special evaluations did not meet this requirement. The agency emailed
the foster care worker notify them of findings but did not include a copy of the report.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
One of three adoptive evaluations was not completed within 90 days of application.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
4

there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please
note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not
be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family team meeting
Page 5
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Three of eight case files did not have FTMs documented prior to completion of an
updated service plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
4/15/21 RENEWAL, CAP approved 4/26/21
FOM 722-08D Treatment plans
Page 11
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Three of eight case files (five of seventeen PATPs) had late or missing treatment
plan signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/8/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/8/20
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
Page 19
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
Five of eight case files held late contact entry. Six entries were 1-20 days late.
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
Page 23
After return home, first month- weekly in-person contacts with
the parent(s) and child(ren) in the home.
One of eight case files was missing one weekly home visit with a child that was
returned to their parent.
5

FOM 801-01 Health requirements
Page 4
A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every six
months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
One of eight case files held a dental that was not completed within the required
timeframe. One dental occurred on 3/10/21, the next was late on 12/21/21.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passports
Page 2-3
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
Two of eight case files did not have quarterly updated medical passports, signed by
the parent.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Some licensing renewal letters indicated the family must complete an
application but did not indicate the application was provided. There must be
documentation in the file to show the date the application was provided in
order to determine the rule requirement was met.
 Borrowed Bed case files had a coversheet to document when items were
received, including endorsement of the reports received at the beginning of
the agreement. However, the agency should update the form to document
endorsement of subsequent reports received for the duration of the Borrowed
Bed agreement.
 Head Start progress/updates should be entered under the education tab in
MiSACWIS.
 Parents & Foster Parents must date their signature on PATP and Medical
Passport to verify they are signed within the required timeframe.
 FTMs completed via video conference must indicate who attended and how
the FTM occurred.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
6

One special evaluation was completed during this review period, in which it was
determined there was a preponderance of evidence of sexual abuse and physical
discipline. The agency recommended revocation of the foster home license.
Revocation is currently pending with the Disciplinary Action Unit of DCWL.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
One special evaluation was initiated after an allegation the foster parent hit a foster
child in the home. Upon investigation it was determined the foster parent ‘swatted’
the child’s arm, on one occasion. The home was found in violation of licensing rules
and a corrective action plan was developed. The CAP included review of the
behavior management agreement and foster parent agency agreement. The foster
parent also completed additional behavior management training.
One special evaluation was initiated after an allegation the foster parent spanked a
foster child in the home. A change of placement was considered. However, the
agency determined a change of placement was not necessary with implementation
of a safety plan including additional agency supervision. Upon investigation it was
determined the foster parent was in violation of licensing rules and a CAP was
developed. The CAP included the safety plan, policy review, additional training, and
unannounced home visits by the case worker.
Overall, it was assessed the agency completed these special evaluations
appropriately and developed sufficient corrective action plans to ensure children’s
safety.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A CAP, approved 4/26/21, was developed as a result of the 4/15/21 renewal
evaluation. The agency had violations regarding FTMs, USP approval, and
participation in development of service plans. During this review the agency had one
repeat violation regarding FTMs. Overall, the agency had more violations during this
review than the previous year. However, the Chief Administrator reported being
aware of the root cause and indicated confidence in developing an effective CAP to
address these areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed with Chief
Administrator (CA) at the entrance meeting. CA acknowledged some difficulty this
past year with meeting timeframes for treatment plan signatures, medical passport
signatures, home visits within the first five days of placement, and difficulty with
parents not attending parenting time. Some of these issues were a result of COVID
restrictions over the past year. While others were due to inconsistent staffing and
turnover. CA anticipates there will be improvement in the next year as they have
become more accustom to process changes that occurred during COVID. In
addition, the agency staffing has become more stable.
7

Interview
Two agency staff were interviewed. One staff was new to the agency and the other
had approximately one year experience there. Both staff reported being happy in
their positions and feeling their co-workers were helpful. Both staff stated their
supervisors were supportive and knowledgeable. Neither staff had any concerns
about the agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST
The DCWL Analyst identified two safety concerns as follows:
Safety Alert 1: The DCWL analyst attempted a scheduled visit to the home on
5/16/22, but no one answered the door. Phone calls and texts were attempted, with
no response from the caregiver.
Resolution 1: The caregiver took the child to the agency on 5/17/22 for parenting
time. The worker observed the child and verified his well-being. The worker also
visited the child in the caregiver’s home on 6/2/22. No concerns were noted about the
home.
Safety Alert 2: The relative caregiver was not responsive to several requests by the
DCWL Analyst to schedule a visit in April 2022.
Resolution 2: The caseworker visited the home on 4/28/22 to verify the children’s
well-being. No concerns were noted about the home.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
_ _______________May 12, 2022____________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 6, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
